properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing rain expected today. A patchy area of freezing rain will move across Eastern Ontario through this afternoon. Areas may receive a couple hours of freezing rain before it changes over to snow by this evening. Ice accretion should be limited to a thin glaze. Poor winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T06:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T15:42:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0364361193.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected to end near midnight tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T08:29:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T22:34:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1501781414.2020
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed bag of precipitation Sunday. A low pressure system from the American Midwest will affect Southwestern Quebec beginning Saturday evening. Precipitation will then gradually spread toward Eastern Quebec. Although precipitation is expected to begin as snow, it is highly possible that it will change to freezing rain over several regions of the Gaspé Peninsula Sunday morning. Total snowfall amounts and freezing precipitation amounts will vary depending on how the system develops. Travel could be difficult. At this time, guidance models still suggest significant variability regarding the system's track. Consequently, there is much uncertainty and the scenario could still change significantly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T08:24:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T16:25:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3459393409.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds are expected over the North Shore. A low pressure system moving up the Eastern Seaboard will bring snow over the North Shore from Sunday evening until Tuesday morning. The snow combined with strong winds could reduce significantly the visibilities in blowing snow. Expect hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility. Stay tuned for future forecasts for more information. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T13:35:03-00:00

Area: Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Locations: Green Bay - White Bay and Northern Peninsula East. Time span: Monday. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop early Monday morning and may mix with or change to freezing rain in the Green Bay - White Bay area for a few hours at first. The snow is expected to taper to flurries Monday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-26T11:27:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T19:28:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1408358864.2020
Area: Green Bay - White Bay, Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of close to 15 centimetres of snow is expected between Sunday morning and Monday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T12:22:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T20:23:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0950209004.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for significant rain and mild temperatures. Rainfall amounts: 5 to 15 mm. Locations: southern and eastern Newfoundland. Timespan: overnight Sunday night through Monday afternoon. Remarks: Rain will begin overnight Sunday night over the Connaigre Peninsula and spread eastwards to begin over the Avalon midmorning on Monday. The rainfall will be accompanied by temperatures several degrees above zero. Areas with deep existing snow pack will be vulnerable to significant snowmelt and water runoff, with localized flooding possible. Where possible, the public is advised to clear storm drains prior to the rain in order to aid in water drainage. Rainfall warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-26T11:27:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T19:28:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2841203074.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dense fog is expected to persist through tonight and Sunday morning for some areas. Patchy fog may last until early Monday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for significant freezing rain and rain. Rainfall amounts: 5 to 15 mm. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Timespan: early Monday morning through Monday afternoon. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as freezing rain Monday morning and could persist for several hours before transitioning to rain by Monday afternoon. The rainfall will be accompanied by above zero temperatures over northeastern Newfoundland. Areas with deep existing snow pack will be vulnerable to significant snowmelt and water runoff, with localized flooding possible. The rain is expected to taper off Monday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-26T11:28:11-00:00

Remarks: Rainfall warnings may be required. Areas with deep existing snow pack will be vulnerable to snowmelt and water runoff, with localized flooding possible. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected to end by this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain this morning in central and southeastern Saskatchewan. Freezing rain this afternoon in western Manitoba. A low pressure system moving through Saskatchewan is supporting an area of freezing rain extends from the international border in far southeastern Saskatchewan to the centre of the province, then curls around the low and drops southwards along the rear flank of the low. The freezing rain over central Saskatchewan and along back side of the low will come to an end midday as the low begins moving to the southeast. The freezing rain over the southeastern corner of the province will become more organized through the morning hours and move into southwestern Manitoba. The freezing rain in Manitoba will last through much of the afternoon, then come to an end this evening. It will not extend too far into the province, remaining in the regions adjacent to the Saskatchewan border. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T01:59:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T16:37:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2548917873.2020
Area: Hwy 165 between hwys 2 and 914 including Pinehouse Lake, Lac la Ronge Prov. Park including La Ronge, Candle Lake Prov. Park and Narrow Hills Prov. Park, Montreal Lake and Molanosa, Prince Albert Nat. Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard returns for Sunday. The pressure gradient will increase across the Richardson Mountains once again as the Beaufort ridge of high pressure rebuilds and a low centre approaches the southern Yukon on Sunday. Winds will increase to 80 km/h with gusts to 100 over the Richardson Mountains early on Sunday morning. These winds will generate blowing snow with near zero visibility near the Richardson Mountains. Blizzard conditions are expected to end late Sunday night as the winds diminish. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are likely. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T15:55:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T23:56:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4190826833.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. SIgnificant freezing rain Sunday. Location: central and northern New Brunswick. Timing: Sunday morning and afternoon. Remarks: Freezing rain will develop early Sunday over western counties then spread eastward. Freezing rain will persist for 4 hours or more in many regions, before changing over to snow in the northwest and to rain elsewhere late in the day on Sunday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T17:24:31-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain this afternoon and evening in southwestern Manitoba. A low pressure system moving through Saskatchewan is supporting an area of freezing rain over southwestern Manitoba. The freezing rain will gradually come to an end through the evening. If travelling on area highways, consult the Government of Manitoba Road and Traveller Information website (https://manitoba511.ca/en/) for reported highway conditions. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected to end later this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T08:09:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T22:35:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3248078259.2020
Area: Aklavik Region, South Delta Region including Ft. McPherson - Tsiigehtchic
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: midnight Sunday night to Monday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds will develop overnight Sunday night. Winds will ease upon shifting to southwesterly Monday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-26T11:19:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T19:20:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3693275855.2020
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts between 15 to 20 centimetres are expected over these areas and upwards of 25 centimetres over higher grounds of the Charlevoix area. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T12:24:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-25T20:25:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2875819143.2020
Area: Saint-Michel-des-Saints area, Saint-Donat - Mont-Tremblant Park area, Mont-Tremblant - Sainte-Agathe area, Sainte-Adèle - Saint-Sauveur area, Saint-Jérôme area, Lachute area, Saint-Eustache area, Berthierville - Saint-Gabriel area, Rawdon - Joliette area, Mascouche area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, La Malbaie area, Baie-Saint-Paul area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds expected late in the day Sunday. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: Possibly exceeding 90 km/h. Location: Margaree Harbour to Bay St. Lawrence. Time span: late Sunday afternoon into early Monday morning. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds in the lee of the highlands will develop Sunday afternoon and persist into early Monday morning. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-26T17:23:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-26T01:24:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3843672296.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada
